page.title: 11RELIGION - PARISH OF EGMERE
page.content: Norfolk is known for its many{ancient {churches.}Less known is that it also has an extra high number of ruined churches: apparently there are 240. Many of these are to be found in {Norfolk's 'lost' villages}- villages that had ceased to exist by the end of the Middle Ages. Egmere is one of these and has{impressive church ruins. Though the{Nave}and{Chancel}have almost disappeared,{the tower}still stands to nearly its full height. The tower is small, but is well built and proportioned. It dates from the early 14th. century as does its neighbour at Gt. Walsingham. As a settlement, Egmere now consists of just a small group of estate cottages and a few other isolated houses. It stands on a plateau between the river valleys of the{Stiffkey}and the{Burn.}It looks ecclesiastically to Wells-next-Sea.
